Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-1, 102-3, 102-4, and 102-5 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-1).

- 102-1 has been revised: It has been made clear that 'name' means 'legal name' (see 2-1-a).

GRI 2021 Description: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-2, 102-6, 102-7, 102-9, and 102-10 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-6). Disclosure 2-6 aims to give an overall description of the organization's activities, activities elsewhere in its value chain, and the business relationships that support its activities, in order to provide a better context for understanding its impacts.

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-2-a, 102-2-b, and 102-6-a have been merged into one requirement (now 2-6-b-i).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Primary brands' (102-2-b).
- The following requirement is now a recommendation: 'an explanation of any products or services that are banned in certain markets' (102-2-b). This is now included as a recommendation in guidance to 2-6-b-i.

Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes: Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-1, 102-3, 102-4, and 102-5 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-1).

Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-1, 102-3, 102-4, and 102-5 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-1).

- The following requirement has been removed: 'Number of countries where the organization operates'.
- The requirement to report the countries has been revised: It now requires reporting the countries of operation, no longer the countries where it has significant operations and/or that are relevant to the topics covered in the report (see 2-1-d).

Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes: Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-1, 102-3, 102-4, and 102-5 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-1).

GRI 2021 Description: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-2, 102-6, 102-7, 102-9, and 102-10 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-6). Disclosure 2-6 aims to give an overall description of the organization's activities, activities elsewhere in its value chain, and the business relationships that support its activities, in order to provide a better context for understanding its impacts.

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-2-a, 102-2-b, and 102-6-a have been merged into one requirement (now 2-6-b-i).
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'geographic locations where products and services are offered' (102-6-a-i). This is now included in guidance to 2-6-b-i.
- 102-6-a-ii has been revised as follows: 'report the sector(s) in which it is active' (see 2-6-a).
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'types of customers and beneficiaries' (102-6-a-iii). This is now included in guidance to 2-6-b-iii.

GRI 2021 Description: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-2, 102-6, 102-7, 102-9, and 102-10 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-6). Disclosure 2-6 aims to give an overall description of the organization's activities, activities elsewhere in its value chain, and the business relationships that support its activities, in order to provide a better context for understanding its impacts.

- The following requirement is now a recommendation: 'total number of operations' (102-7-a-ii). This is now included as a recommendation in guidance to 2-6-b-i.
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'net sales (for private sector organizations) or net revenues (for public sector organizations)' (102-7-a-iii). This is now included in guidance to 2-6-b-i.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'total capitalization (for private sector organizations) broken down in terms of debt and equity' (102-7-a-iv).
- The following requirement is now a recommendation: 'quantity of products or services provided' (102-7-a-v). This is now included as a recommendation in guidance to 2-6-b-i.

Change in location: 102-7-a-i (total number of employees) has been moved to Disclosure 2-7 in GRI 2: General Disclosures 2021.

GRI 2016 Description: Scale of the organization (total number of employees)
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: 102-7-a-i and Disclosure 102-8 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-7).

- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the total number of employees by gender and by region (see 2-7-a).

GRI 2016 Description: Information on employees and other workers
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: 102-7-a-i and Disclosure 102-8 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-7).

- New requirements have been added: The organization is required to report the total number of full-time employees and part-time employees by region (see 2-7-b-iv and 2-7-b-v).
- 102-8-e has been revised: It has been made clear that it is about significant fluctuations in the number of employees during the reporting period and between reporting periods (see 2-7-e).
- 102-8-f has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires describing whether the numbers are reported in head count, full-time equivalent, or using another methodology (see 2-7-c-i), and whether the numbers are reported at the end of the reporting period, as an average across the reporting period, or using another methodology (see 2-7-c-ii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the total number of non-guaranteed hours employees, and a breakdown by gender and by region (see 2-7-b-iii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report contextual information about its employee numbers (see 2-7-d).

Change in location: 102-8-d (information on workers who are not employees) has been moved to Disclosure 2-8 in GRI 2: General Disclosures 2021.

GRI 2016 Description: Information on employees and other workers (information on workers who are not employees)
Overview of Changes:
-102-8-d has been revised: The organization is now required to report the total number of workers who are not employees and whose work is controlled by the organization, instead of reporting whether a significant portion of its activities are performed by workers who are not employees and describing the scale of work performed by workers who are not employees if that is the case (see 2-8-a).
- 102-8-d has been revised: 'If applicable, a description of the nature of work performed by workers who are not employees' has been changed to 'describe the type of work they perform' (see 2-8-a-ii). An organization that has workers who are not employees is required to describe the type of work they perform, irrespective of whether they perform a significant portion of the organization's activities or not. 102-8-d only requires such a description when the workers who are not employees perform a significant portion of the organization's activities.
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe the most common types of worker and their contractual relationship with the organization (see 2-8-a-i).
- New requirements have been added: The organization is required to describe the methodologies and assumptions used to compile the data, including whether the number of workers who are not employees is reported in head count, full-time equivalent, or using another methodology (see 2-8-b-i), and whether the numbers are reported at the end of the reporting period, as an average across the reporting period, or using another methodology (see 2-8-b-ii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe significant fluctuations in the number of workers who are not employees during the reporting period and between reporting periods (see 2-8-c).

GRI 2021 Description: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-2, 102-6, 102-7, 102-9, and 102-10 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-6). Disclosure 2-6 aims to give an overall description of the organization's activities, activities elsewhere in its value chain, and the business relationships that support its activities, in order to provide a better context for understanding its impacts.

- The following requirement is now guidance: 'its main elements as they relate to the organization's activities, primary brands, products, and services'. This is now included in guidance to 2-6-b-ii.
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe the entities downstream from the organization and their activities (see 2-6-b-iii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report other relevant business relationships (see 2-6-c).

GRI 2016 Description: Significant changes to the organization and its supply chain
GRI 2021 Description: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-2, 102-6, 102-7, 102-9, and 102-10 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-6). Disclosure 2-6 aims to give an overall description of the organization's activities, activities elsewhere in its value chain, and the business relationships that support its activities, in order to provide a better context for understanding its impacts.

- 102-10-a has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires describing significant changes in the organization's sector(s), the entire value chain, and other relevant business relationships. In addition, it now requires describing these significant changes compared to the previous reporting period, instead of during the reporting period (see 2-6-d).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Significant changes to the organization's size, structure, ownership' (102-10-a).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Changes in the location of, or changes in, operations' (102-10-a-i).
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'facility openings, closings, and expansions' (102-10-a-i). This is now included in guidance to 2-6-d.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Changes in the share capital structure and other capital formation, maintenance, and alteration operations (for private sector organizations)' (102-10-a-ii).
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'Changes in the location of suppliers, the structure of the supply chain, or relationships with suppliers, including selection and termination' (102-10-a-iii). This is now included in guidance to 2-6-d.

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-11 and 102-16 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-23). Disclosure 2-23 incorporates the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure.

- The requirement to report whether the organization applies the Precautionary Principle or approach has been revised as follows: 'whether the commitments stipulate applying the precautionary principle' (see 2-23-a-iii).

Change in location: The requirement to report how the organization applies the Precautionary Principle or approach has been moved to Disclosure 3-3 in GRI 3: Material Topics 2021.
- The following requirement is now a recommendation: 'how the organization applies the Precautionary Principle or approach'. This is now included as a recommendation in guidance to 3-3-d-i.

This disclosure often resulted in a long list of initiatives, but without appropriate context. This information can still be reported, and organizations are encouraged to do so with respect to the material topics that the external initiatives are relevant to (particularly in explaining how they manage those topics). The guidance to 2-23-a-i now states: 'The organization can also make a reference to other standards or initiatives that it participates in.'

- 102-13 has been revised: It now requires reporting the industry associations, other membership associations, and advocacy organizations in which the organization participates in a significant role. The term 'main memberships' is no longer used.

- 102-14 has been revised: It has been made clear that 'relevance of sustainability to the organization' means 'relevance of sustainable development to the organization', and that 'strategy for addressing sustainability' means 'strategy for contributing to sustainable development'. In addition, the term 'most senior decision-maker' has been changed to 'highest governance body or most senior executive' for clarity.

This disclosure overlaps with requirements in other disclosures. In addition, feedback showed that there was confusion over the use of the term ‘key impacts’ when compared with significant impacts, which organizations are required to consider when determining their material topics.

GRI 2016 Description: Values, principles, standards, and norms of behavior
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-11 and 102-16 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-23). Disclosure 2-23 incorporates the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure.

- 102-16 has been revised: The organization is now required to describe its policy commitments for responsible business conduct, and to report additional information about these policy commitments, such as the level at which they were approved and how they are communicated.
- New requirements have been added: The organization is required to describe its specific policy commitment to respect human rights and its commitment to conduct due diligence.

GRI 2016 Description: Mechanisms for advice and concerns about ethics
GRI 2021 Description: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concerns
Overview of Changes:
- 102-17-a-i has been revised: 'advice about ethical and lawful behavior, and organizational integrity' has been changed to 'advice on implementing the organization's policies and practices for responsible business conduct' (see 2-26-a-i).
- 102-17-a-ii has been revised: 'concerns about unethical or unlawful behavior, and organizational integrity' has been changed to 'concerns about the organization's business conduct' (see 2-26-a-ii).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-18 and 102-22 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-9).

- 102-18-b has been revised: It has been made clear that 'committees' refer to 'committees of the highest governance body' and that these are responsible for decision-making on and overseeing the management of the organization's impacts on the economy, environment, and people (see 2-9-b). It now emphasizes the role of the committees of the highest governance body in oversight: they are responsible for overseeing the management of the organization's impacts on the economy, environment, and people, in addition to decision-making on these impacts.

GRI 2021 Description: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-19 and 102-20 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-13).

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-19-a and 102-20-a have been merged into requirements 2-13-a, 2-13-a-i, and 2-13-a-ii.
- 102-19 has been revised: It now requires describing how the responsibility for managing the organization's impacts on the economy, environment, and people, rather than authority over these, is delegated to senior executives and other employees (see 2-13-a).

GRI 2016 Description: Executive-level responsibility for economic, environmental, and social topics
GRI 2021 Description: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-19 and 102-20 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-13).

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-19-a and 102-20-a have been merged into requirements 2-13-a, 2-13-a-i, and 2-13-a-ii.
- 102-20-a has been revised: It has been made clear that 'responsiblity for economic, environmental, and social topics' means 'responsibility for the management of impacts on the economy, environment, and people'. In addition, the term 'executive-level position or positions' has been changed to 'senior executives' for consistency (see 2-13-a-i).
- 102-20-b has been revised: It now requires information on the process and frequency of reporting to the highest governance body (see 2-13-b).

GRI 2016 Description: Consulting stakeholders on economic, environmental, and social topics
GRI 2021 Description: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-21, 102-26, 102-29, and 102-30 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-12).

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-21-a, 102-21-b, and 102-29-b have been merged into one requirement (now 2-12-b-i).
- 102-21-a and 102-21-b have been revised as follows: 'whether and how the highest governance body engages with stakeholders to support these processes' (see 2-12-b-i).

GRI 2016 Description: Composition of the highest governance body and its committees
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-18 and 102-22 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-9).

- 102-22-a-vii has been revised: It has been made clear that it is about competencies that are relevant to the impacts of the organization (see 2-9-c-vii).

GRI 2016 Description: Chair of the highest governance body
GRI 2021 Description: Chair of the highest governance body
Overview of Changes:
- A term has been changed: The term 'executive officer' has been changed to 'senior executive' for consistency (see 2-11-a and 2-11-b).
- 102-23-b has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires explaining how conflicts of interest are prevented and mitigated (see 2-11-b).

GRI 2016 Description: Nominating and selecting the highest governance body
GRI 2021 Description: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
Overview of Changes:
- 102-24-b-i has been revised as follows: 'views of stakeholders (including shareholders)' (see 2-10-b-i).
- 102-24-b-iv has been revised as follows: 'competencies relevant to the impacts of the organization' (see 2-10-b-iv).

- 102-25-a has been revised as follows: 'describe the processes for the highest governance body to ensure that conflicts of interest are prevented and mitigated' (see 2-15-a).
- 102-25-b-iv has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires reporting 'their relationships, transactions, and outstanding balances' (see 2-15-b-iv).

GRI 2016 Description: Role of highest governance body in setting purpose, values, and strategy
GRI 2021 Description: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
Overview of Changes: Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-21, 102-26, 102-29, and 102-30 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-12).

GRI 2016 Description: Collective knowledge of highest governance body
GRI 2021 Description: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
Overview of Changes: - 102-27 has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires reporting measures taken to advance the collective skills and experience of the highest governance body on sustainable development, in addition to advancing their collective knowledge (see 2-17-a).

GRI 2016 Description: Evaluating the highest governance body’s performance
GRI 2021 Description: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
Overview of Changes:
- 102-28-a has been revised as follows: 'describe the processes for evaluating the performance of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of the organization’s impacts on the economy, environment, and people' (see 2-18-a).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Whether such evaluation is a self-assessment' (102-28-c), since this is already covered by the requirement to report whether the evaluations are independent or not (see 2-18-b).

GRI 2016 Description: Identifying and managing economic, environmental, and social impacts
GRI 2021 Description: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-21, 102-26, 102-29, and 102-30 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-12).

- 102-29-a has been revised as follows: 'describe the role of the highest governance body in overseeing the organization’s due diligence and other processes to identify and manage the organization’s impacts on the economy, environment, and people' (see 2-12-b). It now emphasizes the highest governance body's role in overseeing processes to identify and manage the organization's impacts, including due diligence processes.
- The following requirements have been merged: 102-21-a, 102-21-b, and 102-29-b have been merged into one requirement (now 2-12-b-i).
- 102-29-b has been revised as follows: 'whether and how the highest governance body engages with stakeholders to support these processes' (see 2-12-b-i).
- A new requirement has been added: 'how the highest governance body considers the outcomes of these processes' (see 2-12-b-ii).

GRI 2021 Description: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-21, 102-26, 102-29, and 102-30 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-12).

- 102-30 has been revised: It now focuses on processes to identify and manage the organization’s impacts on the economy, environment, and people, instead of risk management processes for economic, environmental, and social topics (see 2-12-c).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the frequency of the review of the effectiveness of the organization's processes to identify and manage its impacts on the economy, environment, and people (see 2-12-c).

GRI 2016 Description: Review of economic, environmental, and social topics
GRI 2021 Description: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
Overview of Changes: This disclosure overlaps with the requirement to describe the frequency of the review of the effectiveness of the organization's processes to identify and manage its impacts on the economy, environment, and people (see 2-12-c).

GRI 2016 Description: Highest governance body’s role in sustainability reporting
GRI 2021 Description: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
Overview of Changes:
- 102-32 has been revised as follows: 'report whether the highest governance body is responsible for reviewing and approving the reported information, including the organization’s material topics'. In addition, the requirement has been expanded and now also requires describing the process for reviewing and approving the information (see 2-14-a).
- A new requirement has been added: If the highest governance body is not responsible for reviewing and approving the reported information, including the organization’s material topics, the organization is required to explain the reason for this (see 2-14-b).
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-33 and 102-34 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-16).

GRI 2016 Description: Nature and total number of critical concerns
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-33 and 102-34 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-16).

- 102-34-a has been revised: It has been made clear that it is about critical concerns that were communicated during the reporting period (see 2-16-b).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Mechanism(s) used to address and resolve critical concerns' (102-34-b), due to duplication with Disclosure 2-25 Processes to remediate negative impacts and Disclosure 2-26 Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concerns.

- The following requirement is now guidance: 'including performance-based pay, equity-based pay, bonuses, and deferred or vested shares' (102-35-a-i). This is now included in guidance to 2-19-a-i.
- The following requirement is now a recommendation: 'including the difference between benefit schemes and contribution rates for the highest governance body, senior executives, and all other employees' (102-35-a-v). This is now included as a recommendation in guidance to 2-19-a-v.
- 102-35-b has been revised as follows: 'describe how the remuneration policies for members of the highest governance body and senior executives relate to their objectives and performance in relation to the management of the organization’s impacts on the economy, environment, and people' (see 2-19-b).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-36 and 102-37 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-20).

- 102-36-a has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires describing the process for designing the organization's remuneration policies (see 2-20-a).
- The following requirements have been merged: 102-36-b and 102-36-c have been merged into one requirement (now 2-20-a-iii).
- 102-36-b and 102-36-c have been revised: It now requires reporting whether remuneration consultants are independent of the organization, its highest governance body and senior executives (see 2-20-a-iii).
- A new requirement has been added: 'whether independent highest governance body members or an independent remuneration committee oversees the process for determining remuneration' (see 2-20-a-i).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-36 and 102-37 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-20).

- 102-37-a has been revised: It has been made clear that stakeholders include shareholders (see 2-20-a-ii).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-38 and 102-39 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-21).

- 102-38 has been revised: It now requires reporting one ratio of the annual total compensation for the organization's highest-paid individual to the median annual total compensation for all employees, instead of reporting a ratio in each country of significant operations (see 2-21-a). This approach is aligned with existing statutory reporting requirements, which also require one ratio covering all global operations, and with emerging global best practice.
- The following requirements have been removed: The requirements in clauses 4.4.1, 4.4.2, and 4.4.3 on how to compile the information have been removed, as they are self-explanatory.
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report contextual information to understand the data and how the data has been compiled (see 2-21-c).

GRI 2016 Description: Percentage increase in annual total compensation ratio
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-38 and 102-39 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-21).

- 102-39 has been revised: It now requires reporting one ratio of the percentage increase in annual total compensation for the organization's highest-paid individual to the median percentage increase in annual total compensation for all employees, instead of reporting a ratio in each country of significant operations (see 2-21-b). This approach is aligned with existing statutory reporting requirements, which also require one ratio covering all global operations, and with emerging global best practice.
- The following requirements have been removed: The requirements in clauses 4.6.1, 4.6.2, 4.6.3, 4.6.4, and 4.6.5 on how to compile the information have been removed, as they are self-explanatory.
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report contextual information to understand the data and how the data has been compiled (see 2-21-c).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-40, 102-42, and 102-43 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-29). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure.

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-40-a and 102-42-a have been merged into one requirement (now 2-29-a-i). The content has not changed.

- A new requirement has been added: For its employees who are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement, the organization is required to report whether it determines their working conditions and terms of employment based on collective bargaining agreements that cover its other employees or from other organizations. This requirement has been added to understand whether the organization applies similar terms and conditions to those employees (see 2-30-b).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-40, 102-42, and 102-43 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-29). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure.

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-40-a and 102-42-a have been merged into one requirement (now 2-29-a-i). The content has not changed.

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-40, 102-42, and 102-43 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-29). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure.

- The following requirement is now guidance: 'frequency of engagement by type'. This is now included in guidance to 2-29-a-ii.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'frequency of engagement by stakeholder group'.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'indication of whether any of the engagement was undertaken specifically as part of the report preparation process'. It has been removed because the focus is now on describing the approach to stakeholder engagement undertaken by the organization as part of its ongoing activities, rather than specifically for the purpose of sustainability reporting.
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe the purpose of the stakeholder engagement (see 2-29-a-ii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe how it seeks to ensure meaningful engagement with stakeholders (see 2-29-a-iii).
This disclosure overlaps with requirements in other disclosures on the process to determine material topics and the stakeholders that have informed the process.

GRI 2016 Description: Entities included in the consolidated financial statements
GRI 2021 Description: Entities included in the organization’s sustainability reporting
Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes:
Disclosure 102-45 has been revised to focus on the entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting, rather than the entities included in its consolidated financial statements or equivalent documents. The disclosure created confusion about what was required to be reported and about the purpose of the disclosure.

- 102-45-a has been revised: It now requires listing the entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting (see 2-2-a).
- 102-45-b has been revised: It now requires specifying the differences between the entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting and financial reporting (see 2-2-b).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to explain its approach to consolidating the information when the organization consists of multiple entities (see 2-2-c).

GRI 2016 Description: Defining report content and topic Boundaries
Overview of Changes:
Disclosure 102-46 has been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align it more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

Change in location: Disclosure 102-46 has been moved to GRI 3: Material Topics 2021.

- 102-46-a has been revised: It now requires describing specifically how the organization has determined its material topics, rather than explaining how it has defined its report content and topic Boundaries (see 3-1-a).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'An explanation of how the organization has implemented the Reporting Principles for defining report content' (102-46-b).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe how it has identified actual and potential, negative and positive impacts on the economy, environment, and people, including impacts on their human rights, across its activities and business relationships (see 3-1-a-i).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe how it has prioritized the impacts for reporting based on their significance (see 3-1-a-ii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to specify the stakeholders and experts whose views have informed the process of determining its material topics (see 3-1-b).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-47 and 102-49 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 3-2). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align them more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

Change in location: Disclosure 102-47 has been moved to GRI 3: Material Topics 2021. The content has not changed (see 3-2-a).

Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes: - A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the restatements of information made from previous reporting periods (see 2-4-a).

Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-47 and 102-49 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 3-2). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align them more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

Change in location: Disclosure 102-49 has been moved to GRI 3: Material Topics 2021.

- 102-49 has been revised: It now requires reporting changes to the list of material topics without specifically referring to 'significant changes'. In addition, it now focuses on changes compared to the previous reporting period instead of previous reporting periods (see 3-2-b).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Significant changes from previous reporting periods in the topic Boundaries' (102-49-a).

GRI 2021 Description: Reporting period, frequency and contact point
Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-50, 102-52, and 102-53 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-3).

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-50-a and 102-52-a have been merged into one requirement (now 2-3-a).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to specify the reporting period for its financial reporting and to explain the reason if the reporting periods for its financial reporting and sustainability reporting do not align (see 2-3-b).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the publication date of the report or reported information (see 2-3-c).
This disclosure is unclear for first-time reporters, and previous reports are usually publicly available on corporate websites.

GRI 2021 Description: Reporting period, frequency and contact point
Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-50, 102-52, and 102-53 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-3).

- The following requirements have been merged: 102-50-a and 102-52-a have been merged into one requirement (now 2-3-a). The content has not changed.

GRI 2016 Description: Contact point for questions regarding the report
GRI 2021 Description: Reporting period, frequency and contact point
Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes: Combined disclosures: Disclosures 102-50, 102-52, and 102-53 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 2-3).

GRI 2016 Description: Claims of reporting in accordance with the GRI Standards
GRI 2021 Description: Requirement 8: Provide a statement of use
Section 2021: 3. Reporting in accordance with the GRI Standards
Overview of Changes:
Change in location: The requirement to report the claim made by the organization, if it has prepared a report in accordance with the GRI Standards, has been moved to section 3 in GRI 1: Foundation 2021 as a requirement for reporting in accordance with the GRI Standards.

The following changes have been made:
- The 'claim' is now referred to as 'statement of use'.
- The language of the statement of use has been changed.
- The organization is required to include the statement of use in the GRI content index.

GRI 2021 Description: Requirement 7: Publish a GRI content index
Section 2021: 3. Reporting in accordance with the GRI Standards
Overview of Changes:
Change in location: The requirement to report the GRI content index has been moved to section 3 in GRI 1: Foundation 2021 as a requirement for reporting in accordance with, or with reference to, the GRI Standards.
For organizations reporting in accordance with the GRI Standards, the following changes have been made:
- The following requirement has been split: 102-55-a has been split into three requirements (now Requirements 7-a-iii, 7-a-vii, and 7-a-viii).
- 102-55-a has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires including the titles of other sources that the reported disclosures come from (see Requirement 7-a-viii).
- 102-55-b-i has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires including the name of the disclosure (see Requirement 7-a-vii). The disclosure title now refers to the number and name of a disclosure.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'present the complete GRI content index in one location' (clause 6.3.3). It makes sense to present one complete GRI content index, and so it is not necessary to add a specific requirement for this.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'include any additional material topics reported on which are not covered by the GRI Standards, including page number(s) or URL(s) where the information can be found' (clause  6.3.5). This is already covered by the requirement to include a list of the organization's material topics (see Requirement 7-a-v).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to include the statement of use (see Requirement 7-a-ii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to include a list of its material topics (see Requirement 7-a-v).
- New requirements that relate to the GRI Sector Standards have been added (see Requirements 7-a-iv, 7-a-vi, 7-a-ix, and 7-a-x).

Section 2021: 'Reporting with reference to the GRI Standards' at the end of section 3. Reporting in accordance with the GRI Standards
Overview of Changes:
Change in location: The requirement to report the GRI content index has been moved to section 3 in GRI 1: Foundation 2021 as a requirement for reporting in accordance with, or with reference to, the GRI Standards.

Organizations reporting with reference to the GRI Standards are now also required to publish a GRI content index, which includes the statement of use, and the GRI Standards and disclosures used.

Section 2021: 1. The organization and its reporting practices
Overview of Changes:
- The following requirements have been merged: 102-56-a and 102-56-b-iii have been merged into one requirement (now 2-5-a).
- The following requirement has been split: 102-56-b-i has been split into two requirements (now 2-5-b-i and 2-5-b-ii).
- The following requirement has been removed: The following underlined part of 102-56-b-i has been removed: 'a description of what has and what has not been assured and on what basis'.

Change in location: The guidance on the use of internal controls, external assurance, and stakeholder or expert panels has been moved to section 5.2 Enhancing the credibility of sustainability reporting in GRI 1: Foundation 2021.

GRI 2016 Description: General requirements for reporting the management approach
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Clauses 1.1 and 1.2 in GRI 103: Management Approach 2016, and Disclosures 103-1, 103-2, and 103-3 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 3-3). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align them more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

- The following requirement is now guidance: 'If management approach disclosures are combined for a group of material topics, the reporting organization shall state which topics are covered by each disclosure' (clause 1.1). This is now included in guidance to 3-3.
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'If there is no management approach for a material topic, the reporting organization shall describe any plans to implement a management approach, or the reasons for not having a management approach' (clause 1.2). This is now included in guidance to 3-3.

GRI 2016 Description: Explanation of the material topic and its Boundary
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Clauses 1.1 and 1.2 in GRI 103: Management Approach 2016, and Disclosures 103-1, 103-2, and 103-3 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 3-3). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align them more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

- 103-1-a has been revised: It now requires describing, for each material topic, the impacts on the economy, environment, and people (see 3-3-a), rather than explaining why the topic is material.
- 103-1-b has been revised: It now requires reporting, for each material topic, whether the organization is involved with the negative impacts through its activities or as a result of its business relationships, and describing the activities or business relationships (see 3-3-b). In addition, the term 'topic Boundary' is no longer used.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'Any specific limitation regarding the topic Boundary' (103-1-c).

GRI 2016 Description: The management approach and its components
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: Clauses 1.1 and 1.2 in GRI 103: Management Approach 2016, and Disclosures 103-1, 103-2, and 103-3 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 3-3). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align them more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

- 103-2-a has been revised: It now requires describing actions taken to manage the topic and related impacts (see 3-3-d).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'A statement of the purpose of the management approach' (103-2-b).
- The following requirements have been merged: 103-2-c-i and 103-2-c-ii have been merged into one requirement (now 3-3-c).
- 103-2-c-iii has been revised: The requirement has been expanded and now also requires reporting indicators used to evaluate progress (see 3-3-e-ii).
- The following requirements are now recommendations: 'Responsibilities' (103-2-c-iv) and 'Resources' (103-2-c-v) are now included as recommendations in guidance to 3-3-d.
- 103-2-c-vii has been revised: It now requires describing actions taken to prevent or mitigate potential negative impacts, to address actual negative impacts, including actions to provide for or cooperate in their remediation, and to manage actual and potential positive impacts (see 3-3-d-i, 3-3-d-ii, and 3-3-d-iii).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe how engagement with stakeholders has informed the actions taken and how it has informed whether the actions have been effective (see 3-3-f).

Change in location: 103-2-c-vi (Grievance mechanisms) has been moved to GRI 2: General Disclosures 2021 (see Disclosure 2-25 Processes to remediate negative impacts).

GRI 2016 Description: The management approach and its components (Grievance mechanisms)
Overview of Changes: Disclosure 2-25 includes 103-2-c-vi (Grievance mechanisms) and requires specific information on the grievance mechanisms and other processes to provide for or cooperate in the remediation of negative impacts. Disclosure 2-25 incorporates the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure.

Combined disclosures: Clauses 1.1 and 1.2 in GRI 103: Management Approach 2016, and Disclosures 103-1, 103-2, and 103-3 have been merged into one disclosure (now Disclosure 3-3). The disclosures have been revised in line with the recommendations of the GRI Technical Committee on Human Rights Disclosure to align them more closely with the expectation of due diligence.

- 103-3-a-i has been revised: It now requires reporting the processes used to track the effectiveness of the actions taken (see 3-3-e-i).
- 103-3-a-ii has been revised: It now requires reporting the effectiveness of the actions, including progress toward the goals and targets (see 3-3-e-iii).
- 103-3-a-iii has been revised: It now requires reporting lessons learned and how these have been incorporated into the organization's operational policies and procedures (see 3-3-e-iv).

GRI 2016 Description: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: The disclosures of GRI 307: Environmental Compliance 2016 and GRI 419: Socioeconomic Compliance 2016 have been revised and have been included in a new disclosure on compliance with laws and regulations (Disclosure 2-27). The requirements in Disclosure 2-27 will now be reported by all organizations.

- 307-1-a has been revised: It has been made clear that it is about the total number of significant instances of non-compliance with laws and regulations during the reporting period (see 2-27-a).
- 307-1-a-i has been revised: The organization is now required to report the total number and the monetary value of fines for instances of non-compliance with laws and regulations that were paid during the reporting period, and a breakdown of this total by fines that occurred in the current reporting period, and fines that occurred in previous reporting periods (see 2-27-b, 2-27-b-i, and 2-27-b-ii).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'cases brought through dispute resolution mechanisms' (307-1-a-iii).
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'If the organization has not identified any non-compliance with environmental laws and/or regulations, a brief statement of this fact is sufficient' (307-1-b). This is now included in guidance to 2-27.
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the total number of instances for which fines were incurred (see 2-27-a-i).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe the significant instances of non-compliance (see 2-27-c).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe how it has determined significant instances of non-compliance (see 2-27-d).

GRI 2016 Description: Non-compliance with laws and regulations in the social and economic area
Overview of Changes:
Combined disclosures: The disclosures of GRI 307: Environmental Compliance 2016 and GRI 419: Socioeconomic Compliance 2016 have been revised and have been included in a new disclosure on compliance with laws and regulations (Disclosure 2-27). The requirements in Disclosure 2-27 will now be reported by all organizations.

- 419-1-a has been revised: It has been made clear that it is about the total number of significant instances of non-compliance with laws and regulations during the reporting period (see 2-27-a).
- 419-1-a-i has been revised: The organization is now required to report the total number and the monetary value of fines for instances of non-compliance with laws and regulations that were paid during the reporting period, and a breakdown of this total by fines that occurred in the current reporting period, and fines that occurred in previous reporting periods (see 2-27-b, 2-27-b-i, and 2-27-b-ii).
- The following requirement has been removed: 'cases brought through dispute resolution mechanisms' (419-1-a-iii).
- The following requirement is now guidance: 'If the organization has not identified any non-compliance with laws and/or regulations, a brief statement of this fact is sufficient' (419-1-b). This is now included in guidance to 2-27.
- The following requirement has been removed: 'The context against which significant fines and non-monetary sanctions were incurred' (419-1-c).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to report the total number of instances for which fines were incurred (see 2-27-a-i).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe the significant instances of non-compliance (see 2-27-c).
- A new requirement has been added: The organization is required to describe how it has determined significant instances of non-compliance (see 2-27-d).
